### AI use cases for social impact

Artificial intelligence is useful for increasing business efficiency, addressing global challenges, and improving the quality of life for humans worldwide. Here are some examples:

50. Health care can reach remote communities with the help of AI-powered telehealth and electronic health record systems. Telemedicine platforms can offer patients in remote areas medical advice and help to monitor their conditions.

51. AI can help address global food insecurity in agriculture by predicting crop yields, supply, and demand for food while analyzing supply chain disruption and the effects of climate change. [...] # 53 Artificial Intelligence Use Cases + How to Get Started

Written by Coursera Staff • Updated on

Explore a variety of AI use cases, from the more common to industry-specific and socially impactful, and discover practical steps to dive deeper into artificial intelligence.

An AI use case refers to a specific instance when someone uses an AI tool to solve a problem, fulfill a need, enhance a process, or create something new. You can use AI in many situations, job functions, personal projects, and industries to achieve your goals or improve your business operations. As we’ll explore in this article, artificial intelligence use cases can range from understanding your customers better to optimizing energy distribution based on supply and demand. [...] ## 53 AI use cases: a categorized list

We’ve compiled a list of use cases for AI across industries to show how it can transform businesses and benefit society. Review these use cases to get ideas for your next AI project, implement AI solutions in your current role, and stay ahead in this rapidly changing technology.

### Industry-specific AI use cases

#### AI use cases in banking and finance

1. Fraud detection: Algorithms can detect fraudulent activity.

2. Decision-making: AI trading algorithms can enable faster and better-informed decision-making.

3. Risk management: AI systems can determine clients’ creditworthiness based on transaction and credit history, market conditions, and income growth, thus improving risk management.

## 4. Enhancing Communication Skills and Productivity

Crafting emails, presentations, or internal memos can be time-consuming, especially when starting from scratch. AI-powered drafting tools can provide starting templates or suggested text that employees can edit for tone and specificity.

For example, if an employee needs to follow up with a client, an AI tool can generate a polished, professional response based on previous correspondence. This boosts productivity by reducing time spent on communication tasks and ensures clarity and professionalism across messages. [...] ## 3. Automating Repetitive Tasks

Repetitive tasks — such as copying and pasting content, data reformatting, or even renaming files — can drain productivity. By integrating AI tools into workflows to automate repetitive tasks, employees gain more time to focus on the innovative aspects of their work.

For instance, AI can batch-process document formatting across hundreds of files in a few minutes, automate invoice processing, schedule meetings, or generate routine performance reports, all significantly reducing manual labor. This not only speeds up operations but also minimizes errors that often occur in manual processes.

## 4. Enhancing Communication Skills and Productivity [...] When using AI to fight AI, it’s important to implement guidelines to ensure the technology is being used ethically and responsibly. Adopting a formal AI policy and training, emphasizing human supervision, continuing to use traditional controls, and bracing for the future are keys to successfully using AI for organizational cybersecurity practices.

## 7. Collaboration and Productivity Tools

As the scope of AI continues to expand, the technology is now seamlessly integrated with multiple productivity platforms like Slack, Microsoft Teams, or Trello to enhance collaboration. AI can suggest task assignments, recommend deadlines based on project data, or even summarize project updates for the team.

data.title: The most valuable AI use cases for business - IBM
data.snippet:
### Clean up with predictive maintenance

AI can be used for predictive maintenance by analyzing data directly from machinery to identify problems and flag required maintenance. AI is also used to improve mechanical efficiency and reduce carbon emissions in engines. Maintenance schedules can use AI-powered predictive analytics to create greater efficiencies.

### See what's ahead

AI can assist with forecasting. For example, a supply-chain function can use algorithms to predict future needs and the time products need to be shipped for timely arrival. This ability can help create new efficiencies, reduce overstocks and help make up for reordering oversights.

## Industry AI use cases [...] ### Personalize customer experiences

The use of AI is effective for creating personalized experiences at scale through chatbots, digital assistants and customer interfaces. Using large language models (LLMs), these systems can deliver tailored experiences and targeted advertisements to customers and users. For example, Amazon reminds customers to reorder their most often-purchased products and shows them related products or suggestions. [...] ### Humanize Human Resources

AI can attract, develop and retain a skills-first workforce. A flood of applications can be screened, sorted and passed to HR team members with precision. Manual promotion assessment tasks can be automated, making it easier to gain important HR insights with a clearer view of, for example, employees up for promotion and assessing their performance against key benchmarks. Routine questions from staff can be quickly answered by using AI.
